bibl.title: Letter from Charles S. White to Philip Showalter Hench, January 10, 1942

div1.p: White informs Hench that he knew Reed and Carroll well and was the anesthetist for Reed's last operation. He believes Carroll's mosquito bite was accidental, not experimental. White encloses a manuscript characterizing the two men and describing Reed's operation.

div1.head: Letter from Charles S. White to Philip Showalter Hench, January 10, 1942
div1.opener:
DR. J. LLOYD COLLINS
OFFICE HOURS
3 TO 5 P. M.
DR. CHARLES S. WHITE
1801 EYE STREET
WASHINGTON, D. C.
January 10, 1942
Dr. Philip S. Hench
102 - 2nd. Avenue, S. W.
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Your interest in the history of the Yellow Fever Commission
prompts me to write concerning some facts about Doctor Walter Reed
and Doctor James Carroll. These facts are of little importance in
themselves but I thought they might add something to your store of
information.

Doctor Reed was Professor of Bacteriology and Pathology and
Doctor Carroll was his assistant in the medical school here which
I attended (Columbian University, now George Washington University).
I graduated in 1898 and became an instructor or demonstrator in the
school under Reed and Carroll and consequently knew them very well.
A few years later I became interested in anesthesia and devoted a
large part of my leisure time, which I had then, to my work, and was
among the first to use nitrous oxide as a preliminary to ether, with
the original Bennett inhaler. For some reason I had quite a local
reputation and when Doctor Reed was operated on in his last illness
I was called upon to give the anesthetic at the Army Hospital in this
city. Col. Borden operated and I recall the details of the operation
quite well.

Doctor Carroll was the pathologist, on a part time basis, at a
Hospital in this city with which I was connected and I remember dis-
tinctly when he announced his departure for Cuba. It has been my
impression that Carroll was accidentally bitten by a mosquito and
that he did not submit to inoculation as Cornwall has so wonderfully
portrayed on canvas. Carroll returned and lived in Washington until
he died of a heart ailment, a sequela of his infection.

Please disregard this letter if what I have written is not of
any help to you. Your interest in the Commission came to my attention
and I thought perhaps some of these minor details might be of value.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Chas. S. White, M.D. CSW:svf
